author: alexsandronl

description.text:
I designed this to be able to fill balloons with a standard garden hose. The trigger allows the flow on demand and the nozzle assists in filling balloons. Works pretty well to defend the balloon filler from unwarranted attacks as well.  
Print two sets and have an all out water balloon fight.  
Enjoy.

Update 201500621 - Be sure to use the v2 Hose Connector for GHS (American) hose connections.  
I split up the two housing sides into 3 separate sections for smaller printers. I can print the broken up version on my Solidoodle 2 (6" x 6" x 6" build volume). Be sure to flip over some of the housing sections as they may load into your slider with the inside down (flat side up) but you want the inside to point up (flat side down) because there should be no need for support on the housing pieces.  
Put each of the three sections together first. Then, place the internal components into their designated slots. Finally, close the housing with the other half (being assembled from its three pieces first).  
There are two valve options included, a straight and curved. The idea is to use the straight valve allowing it to bend to fit the grove, and bend more to allow flow but be springy enough (and assisted by the water pressure) to push the trigger forward and stop the flow. If you are using a material that isn't flexible enough to allow that much flex then the curved valve should work.

comments.text: I just spent an entire day using a pair of these that I made.  I bought 1/4" copper couplings from Home Depot to insert into the hole.  I think I'll be going back and getting a length of 1/4" copper pipe instead and cutting it to fit.  I don't have the 2 step bit that you get to use with the Kreg jig to create the pilot hole in it, so I don't know how that works.  I used a 3/8" drill bit and it worked fine.  I also placed the jig about an inch from the end of each board so the screws would have more board to grab.  At the end of the day there was some damage to the jigs I made from the drill bit, but not enough to render them unusable.  I'd recommend the 1/4" pipe, cut it to fit the hole in the jig and then glue it into place to prevent it moving.  Also, don't use a hammer to put the copper in the hole, heat up a soldering iron and use it to push it in.
comments.author: ShamusTheTinker

This is a simple garden stake. Can be used for holding non-permeable membrane in place. Print in ABS or it will decompose!

This anti-backlash z axis nut trap replaced the wooden nut traps that are used for the z axis of the MakerFarm Prusa i3v.  I had a lot of trouble with my z axis where one of the nuts would walk out of the wooden nut trap causing my machine to go out of calibration.  Once I replaced this part my z-axis homing and positioning has become extremely reliable.  
This design is for a M5 nut that comes with the Prusa i3v.

To install this part you will need to disconnect the z axis motors from the threaded rod.  Once the threaded rod is disconnected the nut trap can be guided up into position.  
Once installed the z-axis nut will no longer be visible.  It will be trapped between the new z-axis nut trap and the existing wooden z axis guide.

author: groaker

description.text:
Location: Lintong District, Xi'an, China
What is it? The final resting place of Emperor Qin Shi Huang: the first ruler of a united China. This pyramid is an estimation of what the complex looks like: the site is buried, forming a hill. The site has not been excavated yet; the Chinese government has stated that it is waiting for excavation technologies to be more advanced before they attempt to infiltrate the inner chamber which, if legend is to be believed, is not only full of artefacts but should also have a network of flowing mercury rivers. The Emperor died a painful death in 210 BC from mercury poisoning. He consumed mercury pills in large quantities in an attempt to attain immortality (as a result he met death at the age of 39). The nine-storied structure is 115m high, with outer walls 6km long and the inner walls composed of rammed earth reaching 2.5km.
It is surrounded by the famous terracotta army of over 8 000 warriors. While his body would lay in the burial chamber below, the emperor's soul would take a tour up to the middle terraces and then to the very top of the pyramid to survey his empire.
According to legend, if plants were present on the terraces then he would be able to project his soul out from the structure and take a leap, travelling to a further reach of his kingdom to inspect what was going on there if he was needed. The only record of what is inside the pyramid was written a century later and comes from Sima Qian's Shiji:
"In the ninth month, the First Emperor was interred at Mount Li. When the First Emperor first came to the throne, the digging and preparation work began at Mount Li. Later, when he had unified his empire, 700,000 men were sent there from all over his empire. They dug through three layers of groundwater, and poured in bronze for the outer coffin. Palaces and scenic towers for a hundred officials were constructed, and the tomb was filled with rare artifacts and wonderful treasure. Craftsmen were ordered to make crossbows and arrows primed to shoot at anyone who enters the tomb. Mercury was used to simulate the hundred rivers, the Yangtze and Yellow River, and the great sea, and set to flow mechanically. Above were representation of the heavenly constellations, below, the features of the land. Candles were made from fat of "man-fish", which is calculated to burn and not extinguish for a long time. The Second Emperor said: "It would be inappropriate for the concubines of the late emperor who have no sons to be out free", ordered that they should accompany the dead, and a great many died. After the burial, it was suggested that it would be a serious breach if the craftsmen who constructed the mechanical devices and knew of its treasures were to divulge those secrets. Therefore after the funeral ceremonies had completed and the treasures hidden away, the inner gates were blocked, and the outer gate lowered, immediately trapping all the workers and craftsmen inside. None could escape. Trees and vegetations were then planted on the tomb mound such that it resembles a hill."

This gcode will position the print head at each of the four corners (with room to get to the bed adjustment screws) pausing for a button press between each so that you can adjust the bed level.  
It is pretty much the same thing as the bed leveling wizard in Cura except that you don't have to connect the printer to a computer to run it

Just copy the gcode to your sd card. Then "print" it using the ulticontroller. The machine will move the print head to the front left corner and then pause. Just push the knob button on the ulticontroller to move to the next corner. Repeat as needed.

title: DJI Phantom 3 camera body sun shade hood

description.text:
The body attached camera sun shade which don't affect to camera/gimbal balance, but only effective when altitude of the sun is enough high.
I designed a hood for Phantom 3 camera lens http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:854297, but sometimes it causes jello (rolling shutter) effect. I guess the gimbal control is designed based on balance when the lens wears no filter, no hood. When using this shade, be careful high speed forward moving makes shadow at upper part of view. Read "Instructions" for detail. The picture is 45mm version, my P3 also wears handmade CFRP gimbal/cam protector (desgined using CAD), and inside camera UV filter is ND8 (3 steps) filter which reduces jello effect on sunny day. Designed using OpenSCAD.

This shade can be fixed loosely by front legs with the notches, however FIX TIGHT using zip tie (cable tie) or vinyl tape, DO NOT DROP IT IN THE AIR.   I'd prefer using tape - fixing using bond or zip tie makes hard to put in Phantom backpack, or hard to remove when shooting in high speed cruise.   
The 45mm just covers all part of the front left/right prop, that is, perfectly remove jitter effect by prop shuttering (still backlight effect remains when the sun is low altitude).  However this easily makes shadow in FOV - almost over 10km/h or 3m/s forward cruise when camera is horizontal (anyway in that case, props will be in view).  
The 34mm version is better, however only effective when the sun altitude is high, 9-14 o'clock at N35 area in summer (Jun.-Sep.).  
If planning high speed cruise & horizontal shooting, do not use this shade.  Cleaning lens (actually it's UV filter) & remove flicker (auto) in DJI Pilot app is certainly effective.  
Also this shade affects airflow (downwash pushes down the front).  No significant effect in balance (thanks to the flight controller), but stabilizing balance MAY shorten flight time.

A combo dock that holds both an Apple Watch and iPhone. It uses the Apple iPhone dock (http://store.apple.com/us/product/MGRM2/iphone-lightning-dock) as an insert to hold the phone. There's also a version that includes a cutout to hold an Apple TV remote that can be created with the OpenSCAD file. OpenSCAD file included for customization. SEE THE INSTRUCTIONS for details.
2015.06.27: The models have been updated to fit the charging puck and Apple iPhone dock better. If you downloaded them prior to today, you should redownload them again.

You need an Apple iPhone dock (http://store.apple.com/us/product/MGRM2/iphone-lightning-dock) for this model. It does not work as an iPhone dock without it. The Apple dock fits into it. See the photos for examples. The ledge on the watch stand is to hold the Apple Watch in a horizontal position in support of the new WatchOS 2 Nightstand mode. There are several versions included as STL files, including models with low and high watch stand. You can also create a version with a slot for the Apple TV remote (on the larger version) by using the included OpenSCAD file. The only difference (other than the remote slot) between the versions is the space between the watch stand and the phone dock section, and the height of the watch stand. There are cutouts on the bottom to hold rubber feet to help make it slide around less on smooth surfaces. I use Ace 3/16" round vinyl feet, but any kind that fits would work. You could also make the feet cutouts bigger with OpenSCAD, or remove them entirely. You'll need to use support for the ledge, but if possible don't include support anywhere else because it can be hard to remove from inside the cable guide in the watch stand and base. I use Simplify3D to generate my gcode files, which lets me manually place support only where I want it. You can also print a version without a ledge if you want the watch to sit vertically by using the OpenSCAD file. You can create any of these, or other variations, with the included OpenSCAD file. It's mostly, but not entirely, parametric, but some changes will require changing hardcoded values in the code as well so be careful with large changes. Sizing is important for snug fit of the charging puck, Apple dock, and remote, so you may need to scale the model up or down depending on your printer and filament. The models here are designed with very tight tolerances; if your printer over-extrudes at all, or if your filament is thicker than standard sizes, the holes will likely be too small to fit the charging puck and dock. If necessary, you can fix this by scaling up 1-2% when slicing. I recommend printing 0.2mm, with a 20-25% infill.

title: DJI Phantom 3 gimbal camera guard template

description.text: Caution: DO NOT USE THIS AS IS. Printed ABS/PLA gimbal guard does not have enough strength, almost useless when in crash. I designed this as a template for cutting CFRP. See "Instructions" for detail. In the pictures, the guard is made with 1.5mm CFRP board. My P3 also wears http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:890374 body sun shade, and nside camera UV filter is ND8 (3 steps) filter which reduces jello effect on sunny day. Designed using OpenSCAD.

To make CFRP/FRP gimbal guard, first print-out this, test (and modify if necessary) on your bird, fix it on CFRP/FRP board and cut using diamond blade bandsaw/handy grinder. This template is designed for very tight protection but not to affect to FOV, gimbal movement (power-on gimbal dance) nor VPS sensors. However,
  • if using thicker CFRP/FRP board, it may affect to gimbal dance (cut the center front part more),
  • when camera full-down and quick rapid movement (esp. backward), part of the view maybe covered.
    • At the center part, you don't have to makeup holes if difficult (as my picture), because almost no airflow there. The last 2 pictures are another idea of backside guard (no CAD data, sorry). I made it with remnant of CFRP. Lower is better, but be careful not to avoid "eyesight" of ultrasonic sensors; make prototype with paper, put it on your bird and confirm VPS height value shows correct.

title: Filament Width Sensor - Prototype 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Note: Prototype 3 is available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454584 Also, I am selling a limited number of pc board kits for prototype 3 at:
http://owi.storenvy.com/ This is a prototype for an optical sensor that measures the width of plastic filament in real time as it goes into a 3D printing extruder. It is prototype #2. The idea is that with a real-time width measurement the 3D printer could compensate the extruded flow for changes in filament width. This version includes a custom designed pc board as well as a housing. A version of Marlin is modified to use the sensor data.
I added some pictures of the sensor in operation. The sensor outputs a voltage in milimeters (3v=3mm) that is shown on the voltmeter. There is also a video at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HHjDG1jdv5o.
I made some changes to Marlin to read the filament diameter real-time and compensate the extrusion rate. Picture added.
Latest update: I made some refinements to the case design to improve the screw holes and fit of the PC board (try 3.3.stl)
This prototype sensor is now part of the design of the latest Lyman extruder. I worked with Hugh on building the controller and incorporating the sensor into the system.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380987
I added the files for the Seeedstudio order. I also updated the schematic to reduce the parts (MCU uses internal oscilator, no external xtal required). The Codewarrior Eclipse project is also included.
8/2/14 - I added a photo of a sample print showing control on and then shut off mid-print. The filament has a variation of at least .5mm roughly every inch. This is using some new Marlin code I am working on that implements a delay to the sensor readings to handle the transit delay caused by the filament sensor being a fixed distance upstream from the extruder nozzle.

In this version #2 I improved the case so that it guides the filament close to the sensor and seals out external light. The CAD work was done in Cubify Invent (.fun file). The PC board was done in Eagle. The system uses an 8-bit Freescale SG8. I had the boards made at Seeed Studio.
I have ported the code from the previous proof of concept. It now uses an approach to get sub-pixel edge detection accuracy. The imaging sensor has roughly 16 pixels per mm. With sub-pixel accuracy, this is improved by a factor of 2-10.
I added some new pictures and a video of the sensor attached to the 3D printer, measuring the filament width. I also added a graph that shows measurements of filament and metal rods of various diameters to see how well the sensor works, with the sub-pixel algorithm.
I made some updates to the Marlin firmware on the printer so that it reads the real-time filament diameter measurement using an A-D channel on the board (Printrboard) and then optionally compensates the extrusion rate, based on calculated cross-sectional area of the filament. (https://github.com/filipmu/Marlin/tree/Filament-Sensor)
This prototype can be used with a 3D printer to control the extruder flow based on filament thickness.
The next prototype would provide a means of measuring the complete cross-sectional area. The current thought is to rotate the sensor around the filament, thereby scanning the filament at multiple angles. These measurements could then be used to calculate a cross section.
Firmware update:
The code extends one M-code and supports a couple new M-codes:
M404 - N Enter the nominal filament width (3mm, 1.75mm ) or will display nominal filament width without parameters
M405 - Turn on Filament Sensor extrusion control. Optional D to set delay in centimeters between sensor and extruder
M406 - Turn off Filament Sensor extrusion control
M407 - Displays measured filament diameter
I attached a picture showing the compensation working. The nominal filament width is 3.00, while measured is 2.82mm based on the sensor. This results in a factor difference in area of 113%, so the extruder rate is increased by 113%.
I did an experiment where I sliced an object for 4mm filament. I told the printer it was using 4mm nominal filament. The real-time measurement the filament coming through was measured at 2.82mm. Compensation kicked in and the print was successful. Next I need to get some poor quality filament with lots of variation to see if this helps in printing.
Notes on making this: You need to paint the inside of the LED cone with flat black acrylic paint to reduce reflections inside the cone. Alternatively black filament might work as well.
I added some instructions on the sensor terminals and how to calibrate: Board Instructions v3.pdf

comments.text:
See my response to bitouns, he has the same questions. I like the freescale microcontrollers, but they are not for everyone. I have been using them before arduino came along, so I am all set up for them, and I like the in-circuit debugging. I am thinking of a few quick options for getting these in people's hands. One option is I can flash the controllers, and make the boards, but people would have to populate the surface-mount components, which is not impossible - see tutorials at sparkfun using an electric skillet, soldering paste, and tweezers (what I do).
Another option is to port the code to arduino/atmel (arduino micro or nano) and then use an off the shelf board with the Tsl1401 sensor (http://www.thanksbuyer.com/tsl1401-module-ccd-sensor-tsl1401cl-integrated-operational-camera-lens-for-smart-car-27966)http://www.thanksbuyer.com/tsl... . There is arduino code online to read these sensors. Any volunteers to try this? I think its probably easier (and more fun) than learning the Freescale HCS08 toolchain.
I am also looking at other options for making these, but these might be the best short-term options.

comments.text: I recently posted the complete zipped project for the freescale IDE ('Freescale 8 bit code...).  You should be able to open it in the dev tool. Its a little tricky to configure the debugger, especially with the programmer.  If all you want to do is load the firmware on the mcu there is an easier way.   You can use the software that came with the programmer board (USBDM board) in the link I provided below.  If you install the drivers, it installs some flash programmer software, one called HCS08 Programmer.  This software  lets you load the compiled firmware 'hex' file (called FilamentSensorproto2.abs.s19 in the directory called FLASH in the zipped project) into the MCU.  No need for the IDE in this case.

TSL1401CL. Transparent filaments may be a challenge, but I have not tried if there is enough contrast to detect the edge.
comments.author: destroyer2012

comments.text: how does the average filament deformation look like? I thought things go elliptic as well?
comments.author: bkubicek

comments.text: Yes, this current design only measures the diameter along one direction, so would not detect an elliptic filament.  One solution I plan to try is to scan the sensor by rotating it 180 deg while taking measurements.  A simple RC servo could be used to control the position.  Then the set of diameter measurements could be combined together to provide a better representation of the cross-sectional area.  Scanning could occur every couple seconds, so would not be too taxing on a servo.  I could use multiple sensors, but the servo approach seems simpler and would give better data.
comments.author: bkubicek

comments.text: Does the guide hold the filament against the sensor, or is there some wiggle room?  It wouldn't take much movement toward or away from the sensor to change the shadow size by a few .01mm, would it?
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text: There is some wiggle room, maybe .4 mm.  The illuminating LED is about 45mm away, so a .4 mm movement causes roughly a 1% change in shadow size (45-.4)/45, so +.03mm deviation.  One way to reduce this is to move the LED even further away, or have some sort of spring-loaded roller that holds the filament in place.  In practice I have not seen much variation when I wiggle the filament in the sensor.  I wonder if moving the filament away from the sensor also diffuses the shadow edges, thereby effectively compensating for an increase in shadow size.
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text: Nice work! I've been thinking about pressure/force sensors, which however may be more complicated to mount...

description.text: belay glasses that can improve belayer comfort while improving belayer attiveness. The glasses use mirrows which allow the belayer to look up without bending their neck. Eliminating extreme neck bending minimizes typical belay discomfort, allowing belayers to keep a constant eye on their partners and provide a better, more responsive belay. The arms are adjustable to set the glasses to the perfect angle.

Print all three parts and assemble using M3x20 and a spring from a mechanical pencil placed between the arm and the glasses. This allows the arms to be clicked into different positions. Cut some mirrors and hot Glue them in place.

author: Takeaway3DTech

description.text: No drill clip-in filament tube holder for CTC

This thing uses the pre-formed holes in the back panel of a CTC printer. There are 4 square holes each side of the cable loom fixing (perhaps cable zip tie fixings on an earlier marque ?) The 2 'dog-leg' prongs push home into the lower pair of holes and the upper 'pincer grip' prongs hold into the top pair whilst pushing the 2 'dogs' down. The filament is passed through the 2 slots and the tube end is slid through the top holder and sits against the internal stop in the lower holder.
It needs to be a fairly snug fit so some fettling will be required.
My printer uses 1.75mm filament and has a 5 mm OD tube, I think a 4 mm tube should also work.
I'm new to 3D printing and welcome suggestions and comments. Thanks.

author: acek

title: BattleCON DoI Insert
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Every body who owns "BattleCON - Devastation of Indines" knows that the storage solution is a complete waste of brain energy. So I set out and designed a worthy insert with following advantages:
  • Quick access to characters and their tokens.
  • While traveling everything stays in place (shake-test safe).
  • Plenty of room for additional characters (12 should fit).
  • Easy to assemble (no glue needed).

Obviously you need one of those expensive laser cutters. I would recommend that you check out the nearest Fab Lab. If your are at a university where architect students roam around ask them about their laser cutter. Most architect faculties have a laser cutter which can be used by students.
Best results are with 3mm High Density Fiberboard. It needs to be 3mm thick for the plug connections to work.

You can edit the SVG files with Inkscape or any other vector graphics program. Inkscape also supports exporting to DXF which is useful for some laser cutters. To download the correct file you need to know the laser kerf, which defines how much material the laser evaporates. If you are using an industrial grade laser cutter, like Eurolaser, I recommend using the kerf014mm file otherwise use the kerf025mm file for DIY laser cutters like the Lasersaur.

The SVG contains lines with different colors:
  • Green: Is an engraving and should not be cut! Use laser settings for 1mm HDF. Also this lines should be lasered first.
  • Red: Holes of bigger parts. Those should be cut first because the part could move if it is cut out before the holes.
  • Black: Contours of bigger parts, should be cut last.
Look at the pictures in the gallery. Some force is needed for assembly. A rubber hammer will be your friend.

comments.text: Impressive! This has a very professional look to it. What software tools did you use to design it?

description.text: This is a camera mount for the Robo 3D R1 printer.  It's held securely in place by the glass, so it is easily removable.  The camera mounting plate is attached with 3mm fasteners or you can stick your GoPro holder on there.  The 'holes' version has two 3mm holes 32mm apart.

I printed this with PLA in .3mm height with 15% infill.  It should fit quite securely in the middle of the front of your printer.  Just lift the glass and set it in place.  When you want to take it off to clean the bed, or for any reason, it can be temporarily placed in the top filament feed slot of the printer.

This is a jigsaw puzzle, where you can make your own puzzle from the available pieces. The puzzle size has no limitations. The pieces are a tenth inch thick (.1") and are very sturdy.. Pieces are named according to a scheme I devised to identify their shape. E=edge, 1 = male, 0= female, clockwise from leftmost edge or male. Puzzle Recipes: (width x height) [piece name] (qty) 2 x 2 needs EE10 (4) 9 x 6 Custom 54-piece puzzle

EE11 (1) Make your own puzzle recipe or trying assembling a puzzle using one of every piece.

PLA, 10% fill, on glass, no heat on print bed.  Do whatever is necessary to prevent warping and lifting. Tolerances between pieces are very close to begin with, depositing extra material where it doesn't belong can be a problem along the joints.  
I have always printed the pieces individually, the example puzzle was not meant to be printed. If someone tries this, please post your results.  I figure the tolerance is too close for a successful print.

title: Lulzbot A100-A101 Lid with easy removable 120mm Fan

description.text:
I like my printer to be as easy to get into and fix/replace parts as quickly as possible. I also hate the tiny loud fan the lulzbot ships with. This lid fixes both of those problems by using a super quite 120mm fan and a snap hook that allows you to not only quickly replace the fan but also use the fan itself as the access panel to the rambo board that requires no screws!  
One design includes a exit/entrance port for air, the other does not.  
If you put the fan in the Snap Hook before the lid is mounted the fan will feel slightly loose. Once you screw in the lid it makes the part very ridged and you have to give the snap hook a good pull to remove the fan.

Its a large piece so I printed mine with some abs glue on the bed to prevent warping. I also wraped the printer in a towel during printing just to be sure.  
Do not tighten down any one scew until they are all mounted in thier respective holes or it will make mounting difficult.  
The snap hook should be mounted up, not down.

description.text: Have you ever tried to twist two thick wires together, but the wire kept on slipping in your fingers? No more! This is the WireTwister! It's a drill bit attachment that secures the wires with 2 2-56 screws and allows you to twist the wires together with ease! I've included the Inventor file so you can change the screw hole to match any of your screws! UPDATE: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/wiretwister I've moved this design to YouMagine.

When you are in your slicing software, scale the WireTwister by 10 to make sure it prints at the right size. I printed this with 100% fill, 100 micron layer height and at 50mm/s. This is the link to the screws: http://www.mcmaster.com/#91735a007/=xvpztb To use the WireTwister put your two wires into the holes on the bottom and tighten the screws. Then put the WireTwister into your drill and start twisting!

This tiny m3 case stand design is made to 3d print a damping M3 Foot with flexible material without usage of supports. I spend a lot of testing on this to make it happen.  
Currently I use it for damping a DIY dosing pump system to knock out any vibrations.   
The key features of the Design:

• can be fitted onto a m3 hex spacer (screwing is optional than)
  • can be used it with a 30mm M3 screw

  • can be fitted onto an m3 hex spacer and screwed to it

  • Printable without supports
  • Screw is accessible with a thin screw driver
  • change footage height of cases without a need of 3d printing a new foot (eg just change the M3 distance spacer against a taller one. where you plug the Foot on it)
    • Please let me know what you think about this damper and I will be really glad if you use it for your next DIY projects. Let me know your feedback!

Version 2 is a little bit nicer in that the two hooks are father apart, and it grips the cube wall a little bit better.

author: MakeALot

description.text:
The 1.0 version of the Bezier library included a simple linear extrusion of the bezier surface. The things this derives from added a quick and easy 'shell extrusion', which took into account the normals on the quads to create true 'inner' and 'outer' quads. This thing makes a few improvements to both the normal calculations, and rearranges the libraries slightly to accomodate for future curved surface/solid things. As a bonus, the hermite.scad file is thrown in. At the moment, it only has basic Hermite calculations. It even has a surface thing. So, if you want to play with that, here it is. Also, in terms of library function naming, I've switched to being more explicit and rational. linear_extrude_bezier - extrusion in the z-axis
shell_extrude_bezier - extrusion along the normals So, for Hermite, it would be linear_extrude_hermite, shell_extrude_hermite One of the cool features is the ability to show the normals, per vertex. This is extremely handy for debugging purposes. This, combined with being able to show the control mesh, makes for some nice visualization. I was actually able to spot a bug in my derivatives calculations by looking at which way a couple of normals were pointing. Also, I've combined the bezier functions into the maths.scad library, so there is just one fewer files to download. UPDATE: One more change I forgot to mention. I introduced the terms 'berp' and 'berpm'. Bezier Interpolation (berp - formerly PtOnBez). Bezier Interpolation of Mesh (berpm). I thought they would be fun names, and in line with the classic Linear Interpolation (lerp).

1) Download the maths.scad, and Renderer.scad into your library directory, or into your working directory
2) Create some curves
3) Look at the pretty pictures
4) Print
5) Rejoice!

This is a jig to hold the posts in place when gluing onto the base of my Bag/Bottle dryer. Included is the .scad file if you would like to customize it. Important - one of the tubes is open, one is closed. The open side should go on the base post to allow the jig to be removed easily if there is some glue sticking out from the joint.
I printed this with a raft, since it's pretty tall and narrow.
Drum bracket for electronic drum kit 'Session Pro' and other name badges

OK, I know this is a bit specialised, but if you have one of these kits you will know the brackets break.
This thing was printed in PLA, but I suspect ABS will be stronger. PLA works fine though. I printed using 210 degree extruder and a 60 degree blue tape covered bed, 10% fill, rafts off and supports on at 0.2 . A little bit of fettling to the slots in the 'V' groove was needed, the 2 screw pilot holes needed drilling out (2 mm drill - I did by hand with a hex shaft bit in a hex handle). The main bolt hole was drilled out with a 6mm drill the same way. The bolt hole in the original part is offset. it is straight through in my thing. As bolts tend to be straight, I thought a straight hole would be better and would not put as much (needless?) strain on the bracket.
I have included a SketchUp v15 file.
I'm off for a beer and a para-diddle.
Cheers!

comments.text: the inside wall is there to provide a support structure since the nozzle internal diameter is changing with length. I can remove it for you if this will help but I didn't have any problems with it printing at 0.25 layer height and 0.4 nozzle. The cone is a bit longer than those available here, the reason for this is that I use an airbrush compressor for my laser cutter and with the nozzle outlet being closer to the material it gives a better air flow/air pressure which is very useful especially when I cut multi layered cardboard. The bad thing about this design is that you will need either to modify your y axis endstop or cut your fumes extractor channel (by approx. 20mm), without these modifications the nozzle will probably hit your fumes extractor when homing. I've chosen option 2... btw I used nozzle ver. 1.4.. I've attached picture of the underside of the carriage.

This adapts an 80mm fan to a 2 inch hole. This is the final piece used to vent my Da Vinci printer. Why a 2 inch hole you ask? - That's the size of the hole saw I have. Why vent abs fumes? After reading the following, I thought it a good idea: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1352231013005086 http://www.mindfully.org/Health/2004/Nonoparticles-On-Brain2004.htm I used the Davinci 80mm fan exhaust by philharlow for the piece that attached the vent hose to the printer. Thanks, Philharlow. ALSO, The goopy stuff you see in the photo is extra caulk i had lying around. You may want to use something too as the connection is not completely air tight. Since there is positive pressure after the fan, a little air will leak out. You will probably be better than me at making it look pretty...

This adds a soda bottle thread to the bottom of a 36 oz UTZ Pub Mix container so it can be attached to the vertical "pop" bottle adapter created by VitranAccad.   
After the bottom of the Pub mix container is cut off just below where the ribs end, It can be shoved into the top of the adapter and the walls gradually get narrower so friction will hold it in nicely.   
I purchased the 32oz pub mix at Sams club. Don't forget to clean it well because the savory blend of crunchy snacks won't make for good filament. It is a nice hopper as it is clear and comes with large opening on the top with a screw on lid.  
I attached soda bottle thread specifications if you want to make improvements... but it seems to work well. I took some shortcuts because the finer details will be lost in printing with my printer.  
I had trouble printing with the large opening down, but printing with the narrow opening on the bed worked well. I used a water based glue stick to hold it down, but was nervous it would fall over the entire time.

Use M6 wood screws to attach the holder.

Work in progress: Checkpoint 1 - Basic Design  
This is a SolidWorks based design of a fully parameterized prosthetic hand. The first stage in this project was to design a base hand model that could be used for a prosthetic hand.   
The dimensions of this hand are fully customizable via global variables controlled through a text file. By altering the parameters in the text file and rebuilding the model in SolidWorks, hands of any size and proportions can be built. This customization is extremely important for individuals looking for symmetry between their good hand and prosthetic hand, or for individuals who have smaller or larger hands than the average adult (e.g. children).   
Routing for flexor/extensor wires, the forearm mount, and the wrist actuation are in the process of being designed.

3D design was made from scratch in SolidWorks. Global Variables were defined and linked to a global definition text file. By altering the parameters in the file, and rebuilding the model, the hand prosthetic size and proportions are fully customizable.

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 Expanded X Bed Stablilizer

description.text: This simple part zip ties onto the existing pieces for an extended x axis on a printrbot simple 1405 to stabilize the printbed. The incredible expanded x axis mod can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:383713/#files

comments.text: Can you share the STL files for the x-ends that you used?
comments.author: lasercow5

comments.text: I'm using Jon's expanded x axis mod which is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:383713/#files (I'm pretty sure I'm using the 208mm long ends.)
comments.author: lasercow5

comments.text: How well is it working, can you describe how it helps vs not having it.
comments.author: crowsodown

comments.text: So far it's been great, and I haven't had any issues using it. Without using it, my prints were alright, but the bed would hang down a ton when my x was near it's min or max, so during the bed probing, I would have to hold the bed up with my hand so that the first layer wouldn't be completely screwed up, but even that didn't always work. Using the stabilizers, I always get very nice first layers. Because the stabilizers are so easy to print and install, I highly recommend that anybody who's already using the expanded x axis mod should at least try out the stabilizers.
comments.author: crowsodown

remixed_from.author: MarcusWolschon
remixed_from.title: Spider mount for H4n field recorder (inner part)

title: Spider mount for H4n field recorder for 15mm rod systems
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With the H4n attached to my shoulder rig or camera I noticed that it does pick up some impact noise from my hands on the other side of the rig.
(Most of the time it's not noticeable.) Background
For a microphone you usually counter this with a spider mount.
However such mounts seem to exist only for conventional microphones.
Not for field recorders.
Using the microphone-stand adapter of the H4n was no option as the high center of gravity only allows for stationary mounting of the recorder. This design
Based on the existing inner part for a spider mount for the H4n field recorder,
I designed an outer part to mount it to a 15mm rod system.
In this case, the diagonal rod that holds the handles.
So the field recorder is right in front of your eyes. I'm reusing two of my universal accessory-holders for 15mm rod support systems:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7530 and I strongly suggest to use my remote handle:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7765
to control the H4n. As any way of touching the recorder would be contrary to the purpose of using a spider mount in the first place. Links Photos:
https://picasaweb.google.com/Marcus.Wolschon/20110526H4nSpiderUnobservedPrint?feat=directlink Blog Entry:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/05/15mm-rod-system-spider-mount-for-h4n.html notes With another inner part, you can use this to mount other field recorders or microphones to a 15mm rod system too.
You can also use this part to connect the H4n to anything else that has 2
1/4" (or slightly smaller metric) bolts sticking out of it.

Print 2 accessory holders and 2 frames and 1 body.
Use 1 short and 2 long 1/4" bolts (common in photography)
to combine H4n with body and frames to accessory holders.
Use M5x16 wing bolts and M5 nuts to connect the accessory holders to the 15mm rod system of your camera. You can substitute smaller metric bolts for the connections
of frame to accessory holder.

comments.text: Nice!
comments.author: TONY_PEPPERONI

comments.text: I just added a belt-clip for the Zoom H4n based on this design.

title: The De-Holer, AKA the Debowler Bowl Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Here is an organizer designed to work with the "DeBowler", link below: http://www.amazon.com/Debowler-Ashtray-Black/dp/B00A7W69K6)= The De-Holer is designed to hold your smoking bowls and other miscellaneous pokey things that you may use. This version is intended to be used with four 14mm. bowls and has an 18.8 mm bowl/ vape pen/ etc. hole as well, other holes measure 7 mm in diameter and are meant for small skewers, dab tools, etc. Let me know if you're intersted in certain modifactions, I'm happy to publish a V2 in the future if anyone is interested. Just leave a comment and I'll get back to you, thanks!

I personally put rubber feet on the bottom to prevent sliding around and found it to be very helpful. I've found Radioshack has a good selection of sticker-style rubber feet.  
I would suggest cut a 32cm. (12.5 in.) length piece of foam gasketing tape (not too thick, like 4mm or so) around the inside of the dish about halfway down to prevent the De-Bowler from accidentally getting pulled out of the organizer.  
See pictures for placement of the gasketing tape I've used. The width of the tape I used was about 1.5 cm. Although it shouldn't matter too much.

So I am kind of a nut for LED flashlights. I have and have had many over the years. Right now my favorite everyday flashlights are these little 3watt units that take 2 regular AA batteries. Many makes of them but they all have a 3W Cree LED and are 90% the same.  
Anyway my biggest issue is if you lay them on their side they roll around and off tables. If you sit them straight upright they are easily knocked over. I finally had enough and made this very simple clip mount. The flashlight is easily pushed in and yet snaps in securely. I used only 1 screw to attach as I thought maybe turning it would be handy.
E3D_V6 Adapter V. 2
This adapter is for Printrbot Simple Metal. Place in intruder. Then place the E3D_V6 into the extruder, and tighten firmly.

This case will protect your Flip 32+ Deluxe board. I use 4 10mm M3 screws with low profile nuts. It has access to all the ports on the Flip 32+ Deluxe. This case is specifically for the Flip32+ Deluxe from Ready To Fly Quads. You can find the board here: http://www.readytoflyquads.com/the-flip32-deluxe-523 The Flip32+ Deluxe is a very complete flight controller for any RC model, but specifically for Quadcopters.
Print it, put the board inside, screw it together.

comments.text: Thanks!  This works great.  It is a bit big so my Flip32 rattles a bit inside it.  I'm going to sand it a bit so that the board is pinched tight.
comments.author: TimStough

comments.text: Interesting...  You are able to get the 10mm screws, screwed in?  When I printed it, I didn't notice any movement.  But I guess sanding a little would not be too much of a problem.  My Flip 32+ Deluxe has survived several crashes.  I will check my measurements to see if I have made a mistake on the Z axis.
comments.author: TimStough

comments.text: M3 Bolts 10mm length.  M3 low profile nuts.  Hope this helps.  As you can see on mine, it is exactly the right size.  I designed for these nuts and screws as I have a supply from by 3D Printer build.  So far my Flip 32 + Deluxe as been well protected.  I have to admit to having several crashes.
comments.author: NewtonRob

comments.text: What are the specs on the bolts?

comments.text: I've been working on building a Spazzi using the guide created at http://makeprojects.com/Project/Spazzi-A-Solenoid-Powered-Dancebot/1074/1http://makeprojects.com/Projec... -- which I first read about in MAKE Vol. 27 -- and, if I'm interpreting the STL files correctly, the diameter of the hole being used in the plastic pieces that need to be constructed are approximately 20mm in diameter which would be for the 3/4" diameter Solenoid part #C12-24C12DC-AY that I found at http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Electroswitch/C12-24C12DC-AY/?qs=5Spfce2jDh7%252bNR%252bUlB5MMg%3d%3dhttp://www.mouser.com/ProductD... -- but, regrettably, this part is obsolete. That being the case, I had purchased three of the 1" diameter Solenoid part #C16-32C12DC-AY at http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Electroswitch/C16-32C12DC-AY/?qs=5Spfce2jDh6Ao7rZmM3E3Q%3d%3dhttp://www.mouser.com/ProductD... -- which was still in stock.

title: One-hand reading clip for Kindle Paperwhite (could be modified for tablets)

description.text:
Holding a screen that wide, however light, is uncomfortable for me. I prefer using one hand. Before knowing how to use a 3D printer, I used a rubberband corner-to-corner.   
Three clips and a rubberband are all that are needed. The bottom two do tend to slide inwards, but I'm satisfied enough. You could always modify the hooks on those two to angle slightly.

The gcode is there, but there are the other files. Originally done in Rhino for Mac.   
Prints six clips, two sets in total.

title: Internal Bottle Scraper - Scrapes the remaining contents out of bottles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This simple gadget may surprise you with how much additional contents it can recover from inside bottles of sauce etc. This has proven to be far more effective that trying to use an everyday kitchen utensil however it can be a bit messy... but will minimise waste and save money. The design has been made to be as universal as possible but may not work with all bottles (i.e. with an opening of less than 24mm and/or longer neck than 18mm. It should work with most common sizes... Refer to the images for Instructions for use and as follows:

  • Get a plate or container you want to recover the contents of the bottle into/onto.

  • Insert the Internal Scraper into the neck of the bottle you want to scrape out.

  • Holding the small handle of the Internal Scraper that is protruding from under the bottle, push the scraper edge against the vertical inside edge of the bottle.

  • Pull the bottle up so the scrapers lower edge will also wipe around the bottom inside surface of the bottle.

  • While continuing to hold the small Internal Scraper handle, rotate the bottle counter clockwise.

  • The scraper blade will start wiping around the inside of the bottle and the remaining contents forced inwards so it comes out the bottom and onto a plate or into a container.
    • This only costs a few cents to print so will cover its cost within the first use or two. Even if you aren't worried about the potential to save money it can be of use when you want the sauce (or whatever is in the bottle concerned) and find it is empty and you don't have another one in the cupboard. With the Internal Scraper, chances are you will get out the amount you need at the time... Note: If you like this check out all my other designs!

This prints well on a Replicator 2 with Raft, 0.20mm / Std. resolution, 3 shells and 35% infill.   
No support required. The necessary support has been designed in and should snap away easily by hand.

comments.text: What a great idea,  It's a crime to waste food. Thanks for sharing your excellent designs.
comments.author: calderonf

comments.text: You design the support by hand or you use a software?
comments.author: calderonf

comments.text: The support required is designed in (drawn in) already. Just read through the print instructions and it should all make sense... the bottom line is left support "off" when you slice it and the support necessary will be there in the print. It should just snap away after printing and be ready for use. On most machines this designed in support comes away far easier and cleaner than support applied by slicing applications that build their support into the overhanging structures.

title: The Tikicaster: 3d printed semi-acoustic electric guitar

description.text: This is my take on the Telecaster Thinline, Fender's brief foray into the world of hollow body electrics. The body is built the same way as the original. The back, middle and front sections stack up, allowing you to print a hollow body with finish surfaces on both the front and back, and no support. I modeled the tele body in Cubify Design, then made test prints of each area which interfaced with hardware. With a little bit of adjustment I got the nec, the pickups and the bridge to fit perfectly. Then I exported the base tele body from Cubify into 3dCoat where I sculpted the Tiki faces. Sorry, but it won't fit on a standard printer. I made the print on my large custom machine. Each part took about 24 hours to print. The slots in the middle part are for steel reinforcement to take the strain from the strings. The whole thing was assembled with epoxy and a bit of bondo before being painted. We talked about this on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/

comments.text: How has this held up with the reinforcement? Have you experienced any creep despite having a rigid material in there? I have been thinging of doing a custom tele or strat because I have some decent drawings, but If I print something, I want it to last. :P
comments.author: R3dC4p

comments.text: I had to re-shim the neck after it settled in under the string tension.  Make sure you use lots of reinforcement with any PLA printed guitar body.

title: Full Sized Chip Bag Clip Fully Assembled - Extra Large

description.text:
I was asked to make my "large chip bag clip fully assembled"
even larger so that it will go across a full sized bag of chips. This version is bigger than my printer so I can't test it to confirm the
measurements, but it's manifold and it should be fine. There was a successful print of this bag clip so I've removed the work in progress designation. But you can still feel free to send me a message if you need anything adjusted. Besides making it longer, I added an arch along the back of each
arm to reduce bowing over the longer distance. I'd print this with 30% infill given the length of the arms. No support
is needed. Note that you'll need a well calibrated machine to get
the hinge to print so that it separates and swivels correctly.
.
Once complete, gently bend the parts back and forth holding it
near the center hinge. You'll feel it click loose and then should
swivel freely. Be sure to post a picture if you make one.

author: ES0602

description.text:
I have heard so much good things about StefanBurger's Gantry replacement, to fix variety problems of original TwoUp designs. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248059). However, it was very difficult for me to print them with the my original TwoUp printer. After a few dozen of attempts, I decided to design my own.
  • Lower height in printing ( somehow, my original TwoUp started causing number of problems after z-axis reaches 1 inch above )
  • Shorter print time (so, I can easily repeat printing if something goes wrong )
  • Almost no sagging by tightening screws
    • The new gantry holds the timing belt a bit farer from the extruder holder. So, I added a stretched belt holder (original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:218670) The hardware used in this modification are
  • M3 x 25mm 9 pcs
  • M3 x 30mm 1 pcs ( tighten the z-axis holder toward top-left stepper motor hold)
  • M3 nuts 6 pcs
  • 3/8"-16 inch nut 1 pcs

comments.text: Does it still take off the same amount of printing space as the original?
comments.author: Parizival

comments.text: Probably, you will lose about 1 inch at the right as it is. The loss might be smaller with a narrower extruder holder like this. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:408818

comments.text: I like MarkQV's simple X Carriage/bearing holder- its actually Narrower than the LM8LUU sliders and locks in using the grooves in them. - it adds about 12-15mm (about 1/2") to the X clearance, so using your V1 gantry you actually dont lose much if any area.

description.text: Python script to generate a printable rotary encoder pattern.  This script can produce a pattern of a given diameter split into a given number of segments.

Use the latest version by running the following commands:
% git clone git://gitorious.org/rotenc/rotenc.git
% cd rotenc
% ./rotenc
Usage: rotenc INNER_DIAMETER OUTER_DIAMETER N_SEG OUT_FILE
Where:
INNER_DIAMETER is the diameter of the inner circle in millimetres.
OUTER_DIAMETER is the diameter of the outer circle in millimetres.
N_SEG is the number of segments to draw
OUT_FILE is the name of the pdf file to write to.
% ./rotenc 50 60 16 encoder.pdf
%
http://xgoat.com/wp/2009/08/12/rotary-encoder-pattern-generator/

description.text: Simple angled arm for use with Openbeam.
converted to metric units and repaired in NetFabb

It's official, a gourmet burger is 4-1/2" (115mm) in diameter and has an indention in the middle of both sides to compensate for middle swell while cooking.  
Of all the presses I found, none met this criteria. So here it is!  Simply print the housing and two inserts. No handle needed, easy storage.  
Enjoy the gourmet sized burger!  
6-22-15: Added version 2 of the insert which is a little wider and the bevel slope less steep.  Meat displacement is about the same, just a smoother pattern in the meat..

PLA at 100%, on glass, light hairspray.  
Made burgers with ours today, they came out great.  
My first print at 20% fill got fluid inside of it after using it. If I didn't use clear, I might not have noticed it.  So regardless of color, 100% fill is the recommendation for sanitary reasons.  
UPDATE: Even at 100%, my print let fluid get inside of it.  Then before tossing it away we threw it in the dishwasher to see what would happen.  I can now confirm 3D prints are not dishwasher safe!  I'll leave the files out there, maybe other printers will have better success with this.

comments.text: Try increasing top, bottom, and solid infill percent (increases the amount of filament extruded).  If you use Slic3r, this is under Print Settings, Advanced.  I use 200% for bottom and 133% for top.
comments.author: mlenzi18

comments.text: I'm not sure if it is my printer, some settings, or what, but even at 100% fill, my print allowed fluid inside of it.  Also confirmed that 3D prints are not dishwasher safe!

title: Bird Cage Door Hooks - Hook open Bird Cage Doors for ease of access

description.text:
These little Bird Cage Door Hooks make hold the doors in regular bird cages open for ease of access when feeding, changing the water, rearranging the cage or so your birds can come in/out at will.   
These clips should work with most bird cages. Just clip them onto the cages wire framing in the mid point above a door. When you lift the door up swing the hook underneath it and lower the door into the hook to keep it open. Very quick and easy.... refer to images for additional information.   
Please refer to the instructions for printing details to ensure you print them strong enough as they need to be springy to clip over the wire frame. Once installed the clips should rotate freely on the cage wire frame but require some pressure to clip over the wire during installation (i.e  they are designed to splay open and spring back during installation so they will swing freely but not come off). .   
Note: If you like this check out all my other designs!

These clips are very small so will print in just a few minutes. I recommend printing several at a time as most cages have several doors.   
On a Replicator 2 this prints well with Raft, 0.20mm / Std. resolution, 2 shells and 100% infill... yes "100%"  so they are solid and springy when clipped over the cage wire.   
Note: You still need to specify a number of shells so the machine creates the outline first.

description.text:
Wrench used to hold the bell of a Cobra 2204 sized motor.  
To use place the wrench on the motor such that the grooves engage the bell.  Push down on the yoke of the wrench to keep it firmly engaged.  Tighten or loosen the prop.  
The wrench is not extremely strong and cannot take the stress to completely tighten or loosen a prop.  So it's always a good idea to grab onto the prop when loosening or tightening.

This vice will hold electronic boards firmly for soldering.  The vice makes a good platform to rest a hand on so the vice is portable and does not need to be fastened to the work bench.  
The vice was printed with PLC, the heads and extenders are in black, and the jaws in white.  The jaws  are attached with 4mm screws so the jaws can be changed.  One or two rubber bands are used to provide tension on the jaws.  There are knobs to attach rubber bands on both side of the heads.   The extenders can be printed as long as desired, these are 95mm so they can be made on a printer with a 4 in cubed print space.  The 3D CAD file is included in the files so modification can be made.

Print the 7 pieces in the three stl files, Heads, Jaws, and Extenders.  I printed these parts with a brim, and 20% infill.  The jaws I printed 100% infill.  
The three extenders need to be glued to the two heads  The sides of the extenders need to be cleaned of excess plastic, and filed so the two halves slide smoothly.  Test fit these parts before gluing.  I used hot glue to attach the extenders to the heads.  
Attach the jaws to the heads with four 4mm screws and nuts.  Slide the two halves together and use one or two rubber bands to provide firm tension on the part in the vice.  A small rubber band on one end seems to work well.

title: XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 / 2.0 internal spool holder

description.text: Simple internal spool holder for Da Vinci 1.0 / 2.0 printers.  Tired of their carts jamming and messing up a print several hours in.  Obvilously printer can not be using the chips on the cart (rep/rap'ed).  The single file is the full "thing" while the 2 part is made to print without supports...  The bridge is huge so a bit of sagging as you can see in the photos but no one will ever see and didnt have to waste time on supports.  Little superglue or juice to put them together.  Tossed a couple silica packets in there to grab mositure...  Bonus you can see how much is left on the spool and much easier to swap out colors.

Wil Wheaton said 'Make it so' and the internet obliged. Open it in the Customizer App and you can generate your own!
Customize the text you want to appear on the handle.
Customize the diameter of the tap you're going to attach the handle too.
Customize how large the handle should be. Uses the OpenSCAD write library from here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193 Updated to be more printable. Letters are inlaid into the handle and there is some built in smoothing to actually be able to print this.

https://github.com/hendricksonrw/savorywatt-thingiverse/tree/master/89111-beer-tap-handle Full source code at github. I will make this work with the customizer app soon. If you want to run this just from the thingiverse files you need to download all the files for this thing AND setup write.scad (see the thing I derived from). In order for customizer to work I had to remove write.scad Write.scad needs to go in a write folder and Letters.dxf should remain with your handle.scad

title: Xbox One Kinect Camera Privacy Cover

description.text:
This is a cover for the camera in the Xbox One Kinect. It has a hinged flap that can be lifted open or closed to cover the camera lense. The flap does not touch the lens so there is no concerns of scratching the camera lens. The cover slides over the kinect sensor from the camera side.  
The All in One STL is for the brave. If you have a good printer try this one, this prints the hinge and flap in one pice attached to the housing. I will also add two more STLs, separate for the housing and the flap so that they can be snapped together.

Through trial and error, carefully measuring the Kinect housing and doing some math to figure out the angles of the corners I came up with this design. The housing fits snugly and the flap covers the camera lens.

comments.text: the walls on this are a little thin. Even with active cooling, they warped a bit when printing (it doesn't fit on my connect tightly at all).
comments.author: adcurtin

title: iPhone 6+ vertical mount for Ariel Atom windscreen

description.text:
I wanted to be able to mount my iPhone 6 in my line of sight but with the entire phone protected by the windscreen. This 2 piece bracket snaps together and slides over the windscreen then the phone just drops in.  
The center bottom of the phone is left unobstructed so the power cable can still attach and the mount as well as the windscreen frame are not in view.  
Pros: Simple to assemble; no glue required, simple to attach, phone is protected by windscreen, power input is not obstructed.  
Cons: Phone blocks view of the indicator lights, which on the Atom don't auto-cancel, side bracket is the same height as the volume-down button so can nudge it when inserting.

comments.text: Just tried it out, mount was solid but vibrations caused the video to be very wobbly. Gonna add an anti-vibration solution
